articles.headline: Warm West Coast Reception for China’s Web Czar (Chillier in Washington)
articles.snippet: Lu Wei, the de facto head of China’s Internet policy, was greeted warmly by tech executives, but faced strong criticism from officials in Washington.
articles.abstract: Lu Wei, the de facto head of China’s Internet policy, was greeted warmly by tech executives, but faced strong criticism from officials in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At least one thing caught the eye of China’s Internet czar during his trip to the United States last week: a book written by and about the president of China on the desk of Mark Zuckerberg.

articles.headline: E-Sports at College, With Stars and Scholarships
articles.snippet: Video game competitions are taking off on campuses nationwide, with more than 10,000 students playing in the biggest college league, 4,400 more than last year.
articles.abstract: Video game competitions are taking off on campuses nationwide, with more than 10,000 students playing in the biggest college league, 4,400 more than last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Loc Tran is a big man on campus at San Jose State University in Northern California.

articles.headline: Israel Struggles With Its Identity
articles.snippet: The country’s Parliament was dissolved on Monday in part over legislation that some Israelis fear would elevate the state’s Jewishness above its democratic character.
articles.abstract: The country’s Parliament was dissolved on Monday in part over legislation that some Israelis fear would elevate the state’s Jewishness above its democratic character.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When Israel was founded nearly seven decades ago, its Declaration of Independence clearly defined the new nation as a Jewish state.

articles.headline: Copenhagen Lighting the Way to Greener, More Efficient Cities
articles.snippet: Urban areas around the world are installing wireless networks of streetlamps and sensors that could ease traffic congestion and reduce carbon emissions.
articles.abstract: Urban areas around the world are installing wireless networks of streetlamps and sensors that could ease traffic congestion and reduce carbon emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — On a busy road in the center of town here, a string of green lights embedded in the bike path — the “Green Wave” — flashes on, helping cyclists avoid red traffic lights.

articles.headline: Oil Falls to 5-Year Low, and Energy Companies Start to Retrench
articles.snippet: Major oil companies are scaling back drilling plans and laying off workers, with prices off 40 percent since July.
articles.abstract: Major oil companies are scaling back drilling plans and laying off workers, with prices off 40 percent since July.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The price of crude oil continued to collapse on Monday, plunging to a five-year low, as oil giants began to scale back their drilling ambitions and pare the ranks of their workers.

articles.headline: U.S. Lowers One Hurdle to Obtaining a Mortgage
articles.snippet: The program will offer mortgages with a down payment of as little as 3 percent of the purchase price.
articles.abstract: The program will offer mortgages with a down payment of as little as 3 percent of the purchase price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hoping to lure more first-time home buyers into the housing market, the government on Monday detailed its plan to offer mortgages with a down payment of as little as 3 percent of the purchase price.

articles.headline: White House and Republicans Clash Over C.I.A. Torture Report
articles.snippet: The Senate’s findings on the government’s use of torture, set for release Tuesday, have spurred clashes over the risk that they will trigger a backlash overseas.
articles.abstract: The Senate’s findings on the government’s use of torture, set for release Tuesday, have spurred clashes over the risk that they will trigger a backlash overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the long-awaited Senate report on the use of torture by the United States government — a detailed account that will shed an unsparing light on the Central Intelligence Agency’s darkest practices after the September 2001 terrorist attacks — set to be released Tuesday, the Obama administration and its Republican critics clashed over the wisdom of making it public, and the risk that it will set off a backlash overseas.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Unrest Over Race Is Testing Obama’s Legacy
articles.snippet: White House advisers say that addressing the nation’s racial conflicts is now an imperative for the president’s final years in office.
articles.abstract: White House advisers say that addressing the nation’s racial conflicts is now an imperative for the president’s final years in office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As crowds of people staged “die-ins” across the country last week to protest the deaths of unarmed black men at the hands of police officers, young African-American activists were in the Oval Office lodging grievances with President Obama.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Michael D. Shear
